title: Should I put both an introduction and a preface in my book or just one or the other? - Quora

response.answer_text: Only if you need both. You might find that you only need the one or the other. I wrote a bit about the book structure in my Publish It Yourself Series. The preface is about the book itself, whereas the introduction introduces the subject matter of the book. If you want to write about how and why you wrote the book, put it in the preface. If you want to introduce the reader to the content of the book, use the introduction. They are not interchangeable. Further reading: What Is a Preface? response.answer_text: For non-fiction, you can do either, both, or neither. For fiction, neither. For non-fiction, go by what is already done for the topic you write. Fiction doesn't use either.

It depends on what sort of book it is. You haven’t said. Is it YA fiction? Biochemistry for postgrads? Or what? If the book contains advanced material, the introduction is where you skim over the pre-requisites to make sure that everyone has – or, at least, can discover – the background they need for the rest of the book. If the story of the publication of the book is significant (not just to you), or the book to be placed in a larger context, that’s what a preface is for.
If your book is fiction, don’t put in either an introduction or a preface unless your publisher tells you to.
